metadata.title: Electronic Version of OWASP DSOMM Controls - OWASP DevSecOps Maturity Model (DSOMM)

controls.title: Building and testing of artifacts in virtual environments

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each step during within the build and testing phase is performed in a separate virtual environments, which is destroyed afterward.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

While building and testing artifacts, third party systems, application frameworks
and 3rd party libraries are used. These might be malicious as a result of
vulnerable libraries or because they are altered during the delivery phase.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A well defined build process lowers the possibility of errors during the build process.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Performing builds without a defined process is error prone; for example, as a result of incorrect security related configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Pinning of artifacts ensure that changes are performed only when intended.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unauthorized manipulation of artifacts might be difficult to spot. For example, this may result in using images with malicious code. Also, intended major changes, which are automatically used in an image used might break the functionality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Creation of an SBOM of components (e.g. application and container image content) during build.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

In case a vulnerability of severity high or critical exists, it needs to be known where an artifacts with that vulnerability is deployed with which dependencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Digitally signing artifacts for all steps during the build and especially docker images, helps to ensure their integrity and authenticity.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Execution or usage of malicious code or data e.g. via executables, libraries or container images.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Digitally signing commits helps to prevent unauthorized manipulation of source code.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Execution or usage of malicious code or data e.g. via executables, libraries or container images.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Using a blue/green deployment strategy increases application availability
and reduces deployment risk by simplifying the rollback process if a deployment fails.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

A new artifact's version can have unknown defects.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A clear decommissioning process ensures the removal of unused applications from the `Inventory of production components` and if implemented from `Inventory of production artifacts`.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unused applications are not maintained and may contain vulnerabilities. Once exploited they can be used to attack other applications or to perform lateral movements within the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Defining a deployment process ensures that there are established criteria in terms of functionalities, security, compliance, and performance, and that the artifacts meet them.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Deployment of insecure or malfunctioning artifacts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Set configuration parameters via environment variables  stored using specific platform functionalities or secrets management systems (e.g. Kubernetes secrets or Hashicorp Vault).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unauthorized access to secrets stored in source code or in artifacts (e.g. container images) through process listing (e.g. ps -ef).

controls.title: Evaluation of the trust of used components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each components source is evaluated to be trusted. For example the source, number of developers included, email configuration used by maintainers to prevent maintainer account theft, typo-squatting, ... Create image assessment criteria, perform an evaluation of images and create a whitelist of artifacts/container images/virtual machine images.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Application and system components like Open Source libraries or images can have implementation flaws or deployment flaws. Developers or operations might start random images in the production cluster which have malicious code or known vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption ensures confidentiality of credentials e.g. from unauthorized access on the file system. Also, the usage of a credential management system can help protect credentials.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Parameters are often used to set credentials, for example by starting containers or applications; these parameters can often be seen by any one listing running processes on the target system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A documented inventory of artifacts in production like container images exists (gathered manually or automatically).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

In case a vulnerability of severity high or critical exists, it needs to be known where an artifacts (e.g. container image) with that vulnerability is deployed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A documented inventory of components in production exists (gathered manually or automatically). For example a manually created document with applications in production.
In a kubernetes cluster, namespaces can be automatically gathered and documented, e.g. in a JSON in a S3 bucket/git repository, dependency track.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

An organization is unaware of components like applications in production. Not knowing existing applications in production leads to not assessing it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A documented inventory of dependencies used in artifacts like container images and containers exists.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Delayed identification of components and their vulnerabilities in production. In case a vulnerability is known by the organization, it needs to be known where an artifacts with that vulnerability is deployed with which dependencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A deployment without downtime is performed*.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

While a deployment is performed, the application can not be reached.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Building an artifact once and deploying it to different environments means that only tested artifacts are allowed to reach the production environment

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Building of an artifact for different environments means that an untested artifact might reach the production environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of environment independent configuration parameter, called static feature toggles, mitigates the risk of accidentally enabling insecure features in production.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Using environment variables to enable or disable features can lead to a situation where a feature is accidentally enabled in the production environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A patch policy for all artifacts (e.g. in images) is defined. How often is an image rebuilt?

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities in running artifacts stay for long and might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Fast patching of third party component is needed. The DevOps way is to have an automated pull request for new components. This includes
* Applications * Virtualized operating system components (e.g. container images) * Operating Systems * Infrastructure as Code/GitOps (e.g. argocd based on a git repository or terraform)

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Components with known (or unknown) vulnerabilities might stay for long and get exploited, even when a patch is available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: After merging of an automated dependency PR, automated deployment is needed,

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Even if automated dependencies PRs are merged, they might not be deployed. This results in vulnerabilities in running artifacts stay for too long and might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A good practice is to merge trusted dependencies (e.g. spring boot) after a grace period like one week.
Often, patches, fixes and minor updates are automatically merged. Be aware that automated merging requires a high
automated test coverage. Enforcement of merging of pull requests after a grace period.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities in running artifacts stay for too long and might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Custom base images are getting build at least nightly. In case the packages in the base image e.g. centos has changed, the build server triggers the build of depending images.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities in running containers stay for too long and might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Removal of unneeded components, dependencies, files or file access rights. For container images the usage of distroless images is recommended.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Components, dependencies, files or file access rights might have vulnerabilities, but the they are not needed.

controls.title: Usage of a maximum lifetime for images

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A short maximum lifetime for images is defined, e.g. 30 days. The project images, based on the nightly builded images, are deployed at leased once within the defined lifetime. Third Party images are deployed at leased once within the defined lifetime.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities in images of running containers stay for too long and might get exploited. Long running containers have potential memory leaks. A compromised container might get killed by restarting the container (e.g. in case the attacker has not reached the persistence layer).

controls.title: Usage of a short maximum lifetime for images

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A good practice is to perform the build and deployment daily or even just-in-time, when a new component (e.g. package) for the image is available.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities in running containers stay for too long and might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Threat modeling is performed by using reviewing user stories and producing security driven data flow diagrams.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Inadequate identification of business and technical risks.

controls.title: Conduction of simple threat modeling on business level

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Threat modeling of business functionality is performed during the product backlog creation to facilitate early detection of security defects.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Business related threats are discovered too late in the development and deployment process.

controls.title: Conduction of simple threat modeling on technical level

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Threat modeling of technical features is performed during the product sprint planning.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Technical related threats are discovered too late in the development and deployment process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Advanced abuse stories are created as part of threat modeling activities.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Simple user stories are not going deep enough. Relevant security considerations are performed. Security flaws are discovered too late in the development and deployment process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Abuse stories are created during the creation of user stories.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

User stories mostly don't consider security implications. Security flaws are discovered too late in the development and deployment process.

controls.title: Creation of threat modeling processes and standards

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Creation of threat modeling processes and standards through the organization helps to enhance the security culture and provide more structure to the threat model exercises.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Inadequate identification of business and technical risks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Transparent and timely communication of the security targets by senior management is essential to ensure teams' buy-in and support.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Employees don't know their organizations security targets. Therefore security is not considered during development and administration as much as it should be.

controls.title: Ad-Hoc Security trainings for software developers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Provide security awareness training for all personnel involved in software development Ad-Hoc.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Understanding security is hard and personnel needs to be trained on it. Otherwise, flaws like an SQL Injection might be introduced into the software which might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By aligning security Subject Matter Experts with project teams, a higher security standard can be achieved.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The concept of Security Champions might suggest that only he/she is responsible for security. However, everyone in the project team should be responsible for security.

controls.title: Conduction of build-it, break-it, fix-it contests

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The build-it, break-it, fix-it contest allows to train people with security related roles like security champions the build, break and fix part of a secure application. This increases the learning of building secure components.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Understanding security is hard, even for security champions and the conduction of security training often focuses on breaking a component instead of building a component secure.

controls.title: Conduction of collaborative security checks with developers and system administrators

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Periodically security reviews of source code (SCA), in which security SME, developers and operations are involved, are effective at increasing the robustness of software and the security knowledge of the teams involved.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Security checks by external companies do not increase the understanding of an application/system for internal employees.

controls.title: Conduction of collaborative team security checks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mutual security testing the security of other teams project enhances security awareness and knowledge.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Development teams limited insight over security practices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: War Games like activities help train for incidents. Security SMEs create attack scenarios in a testing environment enabling the trainees to learn how to react in case of an incident.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Understanding incident response plans during an incident is hard and ineffective.

controls.title: Each team has a security champion

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each team defines an individual to be responsible for security. These individuals are often referred to as 'security champions'

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

No one feels directly responsible for security and the security champion does not have enough time to allocate to each team.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As a security team, be open for questions and hints during defined office hours. x x d

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Developers and Operations are not in contact with the security team and therefore do not ask prior implementation of (known or unknown) threats-

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Provide security awareness training for all internal personnel involved in software development on a regular basis like twice in a year for 1-3 days.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Understanding security is hard.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Provide security awareness training for all personnel including externals involved in software development on a regular basis.

Risk:

Understanding security is hard.

controls.title: Regular security training of security champions

Risk:

Understanding security is hard, even for security champions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Good communication and transparency encourages cross-organizational support. Gamification of security is also known to help, examples include T-Shirts, mugs, cups, gift cards and 'High-Fives'.

Risk:

Employees are not getting excited about security.

parts.prose: By coaching teams on security topics using for example the samman coaching method, teams internalize security practices as new habits in their development process.

Risk:

Training does not change behaviour. Therefore, even if security practices are understood, it's likely that they are not performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following areas of code tend to have a high-risk of containing security vulnerabilities:
  - Crypto implementations / usage
  - Parser, unparser
  - System configuration
  - Authentication, authorization
  - Session management
  - Request throttling
  - :unicorn: (self-developed code, only used in that one software)

Risk:

Understanding security is hard.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security consulting to teams is given on request. The security consultants can be internal or external.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not asking a security expert when questions regarding security appear might lead to flaws.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Running a 'lessons learned' session after an incident helps drive continuous improvement. Regular meetings with security champions are a good place to share and discuss lessons learned.

parts.name: guidance

Risk:

After an incident, a similar incident might reoccur.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Participate with your whole team in a simple mob hacking session organized by the Security Champion Guild.
In the session the guild presents a vulnerable application and together you look at possible exploits.
Just like in mob programming there is one driver and several navigators.

parts.name: guidance

Risk:

Understanding security is hard.

controls.title: Approval by reviewing any new version

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On each new version (e.g. Pull Request) of source code or infrastructure components a security peer review of the changes is performed (two eyes principle) and approval given by the reviewer.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

An individual might forget to implement security measures to protect source code or infrastructure components.

controls.title: Definition of a change management process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each change of a system is automatically recorded and adequately logged.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The impact of a change is not controlled because these are not recorded or documented.

controls.title: Definition of simple BCDR practices for critical components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By understanding and documenting a business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) plan, the overall availability of systems and applications is increased. Success factors like responsibilities, Service Level Agreements, Recovery Point Objectives, Recovery Time Objectives or Failover must be fully documented and understood by the people involved in the recovery.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

If the disaster recovery actions are not clear, you risk slow reaction and remediation delays. This applies to cyber attacks as well as natural emergencies, such as a power outage.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Defining the protection requirement. 
The protection requirements for an application should consider:
- Processed data criticality
- Application accessibility (internal vs. external)
- Regulatory compliance
- Other relevant factors

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not defining the protection requirement of applications can lead to wrong prioritization, delayed remediation of 
critical security issues, increasing the risk of exploitation and potential damage to the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Containers are running as non-root. This can be enforced in the image itself or during runtime parameters 
(e.g. `podman  run --user [...]`).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

There are various reasons to run a container as non-root. Samples are listed:
## Container Escape Vectors

- Root privileges significantly increase the chance of breaking container isolation
- Root access can be leveraged to exploit kernel vulnerabilities
- Compromised root containers provide attackers with maximum privileges inside the container
- Greater potential for escaping container boundaries to the host system

## Host System Vulnerabilities

Root containers can potentially:

- Mount sensitive host filesystems
- Access critical device files
- Modify host network settings
- Interact with host system processes
- Override security controls

## Resource Management Issues

Root privileges may allow containers to:

- Bypass resource quotas and limits
- Modify control group (cgroup) settings
- Interfere with other containers' resources
- Circumvent memory and CPU restrictions

Security Boundary Weakening

- Violates the principle of least privilege
- Provides unnecessary elevated permissions
- Expands the potential attack surface
- Increases the impact of a successful compromise

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
* Use modern secure frameworks such as React/Angular/Vue/Svelte. The default method here renders data in a safe way.
* Use established and well-maintained encoding libraries such as OWASP’s Java Encoder and Microsoft’s AntiXSS.
* Implement content security policies (CSP) to restrict the types of content that can be loaded and executed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

If an attacker manages to slip though your input validation, the attacker may gain control over the user session or execute arbitrary actions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
* Identify which of the types your application is using. Check that you use:
  * Use _parametrized queries_ (or _prepared statements_)
* For database queries, you may also use:
  * Use _stored procedures_ ()
  * Use ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) tools that automatically handle input sanitization

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Systems vulnerable to injections may lead to data breaches, loss of data, 
unauthorized alteration of data, or complete database compromise or downtime.

This applies to SQL, NoSql, LDAP, XPath, email headers OS commands, etc.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Implement and enforce security headers across all applications and services

Implementation Methods:
1. Reverse Proxy/Load Balancer: Configure at nginx/Apache level
2. Web Application: Implement in the application middleware
3. Service Mesh: Configure at the ingress controller level
4. Standard Docker Image: Use secure base images with preset headers

Remove or Secure:
- Server header: Hide server version information
- X-Powered-By: Remove technology stack information

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Missing or misconfigured security headers can lead to various security vulnerabilities, e.g.:
- Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) due to missing Content Security Policy
- Clickjacking attacks due to missing X-Frame-Options
- Information disclosure through Server header exposure
- SSL/TLS downgrade attacks due to missing HSTS
- Cross-site scripting and injection due to missing security headers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: .gitignore files help prevent accidental commits of secrets, debug, or workstation specific data

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unintended leakage of secrets, debug, or workstation specific data

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mandate blocking of force pushes in the version control platform.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Misuse of force push can lead to loss of work. It may overwrite remote 
branches without warning, potentially erasing valuable contributions from team members. This can disrupt collaboration, 
cause data loss, and create confusion in the development process.

Bypassing the pull request process might remove an important code review step. 
This increases the risk of merging low-quality or buggy code into the main branch, potentially introducing bugs in the codebase.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implement a policy where any commits made after a pull request has been approved automatically revoke that approval, necessitating a fresh review and re-approval process.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Intentional or accidental alterations in critical branches like main (or master) through post-approval code additions.

controls.title: Local development linting & style checks performed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Integrate static code analysis tools in IDEs.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Insecure or unmaintainable code base.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Define source code management system policies (e.g. branch protection rules, mandatory code reviews from at least one person, ...) to ensure that changes to critical branches are only possible under defined conditions. These policies can be implemented at repository level or organization level, depending on the source code management system.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Intentional or accidental alterations in critical branches like main (or master).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mandate passing of security related specified status checks, like successful builds or static application security tests, before proceeding.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Organizations risk introducing broken builds, quality issues, and security vulnerabilities into their codebase.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Version artifacts in order to identify deployed features and issues. This includes application and infrastructure code, jenkins configuration, container and virtual machine images.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Deployment of untracked artifacts.

controls.title: Applications are running in virtualized environments

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Applications are running in a dedicated and isolated virtualized environments.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Through a vulnerability in one service on a server, the attacker gains access to other services running on the same server.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Performing automated periodical backups are used. Backup before deployment can help facilitate deployments whilst testing the backup restore processes.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

If errors are experienced during the deployment process you want to deploy an old release. However, due to changes in the database this is often unfeasible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Harden environments according to best practices. Level 1 and partially level 2 from hardening practices like 'CIS Kubernetes Bench for Security' should be considered.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Using default configurations for a cluster environment leads to potential risks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Having a whitelist and explicitly allowing egress traffic provides the ability to stop unauthorized data leakage.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

A compromised infrastructure component might try to send out stolen data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Harden environments according to best practices. Level 2 and partially level 3 from hardening practices like 'CIS Kubernetes Bench for Security' should be considered.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Using default configurations for a cluster environment leads to potential risks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Redundancies in the IT systems

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The availability of IT systems might be disturbed due to components failures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems are setup by code. A full environment can be provisioned. In addition, software like Jenkins 2 can be setup and configured in in code too. The code should be stored in a version control system.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

No tracking of changes in systems might lead to errors in the configuration. In additions, it might lead to unauthorized changes. An examples is jenkins.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The communication between virtual environments is controlled and regulated.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Virtual environments in default settings are able to access other virtual environments on the network stack. By using virtual machines, it is often possible to connect to other virtual machines. By using docker, one bridge is used by default so that all containers on one host can communicate with each other.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System calls are limited.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

System events (system calls) can lead to privilege escalation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Two ore more factor authentication for all accounts on all (important) systems and applications

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

One factor authentication is more vulnerable to brute force attacks and is considered less secure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Two ore more factor authentication for all privileged accounts on systems and applications

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

One factor authentication is more vulnerable to brute force attacks and is considered less secure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A microservice-architecture helps to have small components, which are more easy to test.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Monolithic applications are hard to test.

controls.title: Production near environments are used by developers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of infrastructure as code helps to create a production near environment. The developer needs to be trained in order to setup a local development environment. In addition, it should be possible to create production like test data. Often personal identifiable information is anonymized in order to comply with data protection laws.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

In case an errors occurs in production, the developer need to be able to create a production near environment on a local development environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The usage of a (role based) access control helps to restrict system access to authorized users.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Everyone is able to get unauthorized access to information on systems or to modify information unauthorized on systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All internal systems are using simple authentication

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Attackers a gaining access to internal systems and application interfaces

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A randomized periodically shutdown of systems makes sure, that nobody will perform manual changes to a system.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Due to manual changes on a system, they are not replaceable anymore. In case of a crash it might happen that a planned redundant system is unavailable. In addition, it is hard to replay manual changes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of a separate account dedicated for security activities.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Having security auditing in the same account as infrastructure and applications at the cloud provide might cause evil administrators (or threat actors taking over an account of an administrator) to alter evidence like audit logs.

controls.title: Usage of edge encryption at transit

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
By using encryption at the edge of traffic in transit, it is impossible
or at least harder to sniff credentials or information being outside of the organization.

Using standard secure protocols like HTTPS is recommended.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Evil actors might be able to perform a man in the middle attack and sniff confidential information (e.g. authentication factors like passwords).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By using encryption at rest, it is impossible or at least harder to to read information.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Evil actors might be able to access data and read information, e.g. from physical hard disks.

controls.title: Usage of internal encryption at transit

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By using encryption internally, e.g. inside of a cluster, it is impossible or at least harder to sniff credentials.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Evil actors within the organization of traffic in transit might be able to perform a man in the middle attack and sniff confidential information (e.g. authentication factors like passwords)

controls.title: Usage of security by default for components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hardening of components is important, specially for image on which other teams base on. Hardening should be performed on the operation system and on the services inside (e.g. Nginx or a Java-Application).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Components (images, libraries, applications) are not hardened.

controls.title: Usage of test and production environments

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A test and a production like environment is used

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Security tests are not running regularly because test environments are missing

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All virtual environments are using resource limits on hard disks, memory and CPU

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Denial of service (internally by an attacker or unintentionally by a bug) on one service effects other services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An advanced WAF protection level includes rigorous input validation, rejecting any parameters not explicitly required, and custom rule sets that are dynamically updated in response to emerging threats.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The presence of sophisticated threats necessitates a robust defense strategy where application inputs are meticulously scrutinized for security breaches, including advanced persistent threats and zero-day vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implementing a web application firewall (WAF) is a critical security control. At a baseline level, the objective is to finely balance the reduction of false positives, maintaining user experience, against a potential increase in the less noticeable false negatives.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerable input, such as exploits, can infiltrate the application via numerous entry points, posing a significant security threat.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A WAF deployed with a medium level of protection strengthens the security posture by striking a more advanced balance between the detection of genuine threats and the minimization of false alarms.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The threat from malicious inputs remains high, with exploits seeking to exploit any vulnerabilities present at the various points of entry to the application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A centralized logging system is used and applications logs (including application exceptions) are shipped to it.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Local stored logs can be unauthorized manipulated by attackers with system access or might be corrupt after an incident. In addition, it is hard to perform an correlation of logs. This leads attacks, which can be performed silently.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By using centralized logging logs are protected against unauthorized modification.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Local stored system logs can be unauthorized manipulated by attackers or might be corrupt after an incident. In addition, it is hard to perform a aggregation of logs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Events are correlated on one system. For example the correlation and visualization of failed login attempts combined with successful login attempts.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Detection of security related events with hints on different systems/tools/metrics is not possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security-relevant events like login/logout or creation, change, deletion of users should be logged.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

* No track of security-relevant events makes it harder to analyze an incident.
* Security incident analysis takes significantly less time with proper security events, such that an attack can be stopped before the attacker reaches his goal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A concept how to log PII is documented and applied.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Personal identifiable information (PII) is logged and the privacy law (e.g. General Data Protection Regulation) is not followed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protocols are visualized in a simple to use real time monitoring system. The GUI gives the ability to search for special attributes in the protocol.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

System and application protocols are not visualized properly which leads to no or very limited logging assessment. Specially developers might have difficulty to read applications logs with unusually tools like the Linux tool 'cat'

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All defects from the dimension Test- and Verification are instrumented.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

People are not looking into tests results. Vulnerabilities not recolonized, even they are detected by tools.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Advanced metrics are gathered in relation to availability and stability. For example unplanned downtime's per year.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Trends and advanced attacks are not detected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Thresholds for metrics are set. In case the thresholds are reached, alarms are send out. Which should get attention due to the critically.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Incidents are discovered after they happened.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Gathering of system calls.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

System events (system calls) trends and attacks are not detected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Usage of Coverage- and control-metrics to show the effectiveness of the security program. Coverage is the degree in 
        which a specific security control for a specific target group is applied with all resources.
        The control degree shows the actual application of security standards and security-guidelines. Examples are gathering information on anti-virus, anti-rootkits, patch management, server configuration and vulnerability management.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The effectiveness of configuration, patch and vulnerability management is unknown.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Deactivation of unused metrics helps to free resources.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

High resources are used while gathering unused metrics.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Gathering of defense metrics like TCP/UDP sources enables to assume the geographic location of the request.
Assuming a Kubernetes cluster with an egress-traffic filter (e.g. IP/domain based), an alert might be send out in case of every violation. For ingress-traffic, alerting might not even be considered.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

IDS/IPS systems like packet- or application-firewalls detect and prevent attacks. It is not known how many attacks has been detected and blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Meaningful grouping of metrics helps to speed up analysis.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The analysis of metrics takes long.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Metrics during tests helps to identify programming errors.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Changes might cause high load due to programming errors.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implement cost budgets. Setting of an alert threshold and sending out errors when it is reached. In the best case, a second threshold with a limit is set so that the cost can not go higher.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not monitoring costs might lead to unexpected high resource consumption and a high invoice.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By having an internal accessible screen with a security related dashboards helps to visualize incidents.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Security related information is discovered too late during an incident.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Gathering of application metrics helps to identify incidents like brute force attacks, login/logout patterns, and unusual spikes in activity. Key metrics to monitor include:
  - Authentication attempts (successful/failed logins)
  - Transaction volumes and patterns (e.g. orders, payments)
  - API call rates and response times
  - User session metrics
  - Resource utilization

Example: An e-commerce application normally processes 100 orders per hour. A sudden spike to 1000 orders per hour could indicate either:
 - A legitimate event (unannounced marketing campaign, viral social media post)
 - A security incident (automated bulk purchase bots, credential stuffing attack)

By monitoring these basic metrics, teams can quickly investigate abnormal patterns and determine if they represent security incidents requiring response.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Attacks on an application are not recognized.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cloud providers often provide insight into budgets. A threshold and alarming for the budget is set.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not getting notified about reaching the end of the budget (e.g. due to a denial of service) creates unexpected costs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Gathering of system metrics helps to identify incidents and specially bottlenecks like in CPU usage, memory usage and hard disk usage.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Without simple metrics analysis of incidents are hard. In case an application uses a lot of CPU from time to time, it is hard for a developer to find out the source with Linux commands.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: By the definition of target groups for incidents people are only getting alarms for incidents they are in charge for.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

People are bored (ignorant) of incident alarm messages, as they are not responsible to react.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Metrics are visualized in real time in a user friendly way.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not visualized metrics lead to restricted usage of metrics.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Measurement and communication of the number of vulnerabilities handled per severity level for components such as applications, ensuring alignment with SLAs. 
The rate should be broken down by team, product, application, repository, and/or service. This analysis should be conducted at least quarterly.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not communicating how many applications are adhering to SLAs based on the criticality of vulnerabilities can lead to delayed remediation of 
critical security issues, increasing the risk of exploitation and potential damage to the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Creation and response statistics (e.g. Mean Time to Resolution) of findings. This is also referred to as _Mean Time to Resolve_.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

No or delayed reaction to findings leads to potential exploitation of findings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Measurement and communication of vulnerabilities per severity for components like applications. At least quarterly.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Failing to convey the number of vulnerabilities by severity might undermine the effectiveness of product teams. This might lead to ignorance of findings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Measurement and communication of vulnerabilities per severity for components like applications and split it depending on the layer (e.g. app/infra). At least quarterly.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Failing to convey the number of vulnerabilities by severity and layer (app/infra) might undermine the effectiveness of product teams. This might lead to ignorance of findings.

controls.title: Patching mean time to resolution via PR

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Measurement and communication of patching Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR) in alignment with Service Level Agreements (SLAs), conducted at least on a quarterly basis.
This includes the measurement of the existence of a properly configured automated pull request (PR) tool (e.g., Dependabot or Renovate) in a repository. 
In addition, the measurement of the time from opening an automated PR to merging it.

Average time to patch is visualized per component/project/team.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Without measuring Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR) related to patching, it is challenging to identify delays in the patching process. Unaddressed vulnerabilities can be exploited by attackers, leading to potential security breaches and data loss.

controls.title: Patching mean time to resolution via production

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Measurement and communication of the time from the availability of a patch to its deployment in production in alignment with Service Level Agreements (SLAs), conducted at least on a quarterly basis.
Average time to patch is visualized per component/project/team.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Without measuring Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR) related to patching, it is challenging to identify delays in the patching process. Unaddressed vulnerabilities can be exploited by attackers, leading to potential security breaches and data loss.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Measurement and communication of how many of the vulnerabilities handling per severity for components like applications are aligned to SLAs. 
This is performed for the hole organization and doesn't need to be broken down (yet) on team/product/application. 
At least quarterly.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not communicating how many applications are adhering to SLAs based on the criticality of vulnerabilities can lead to delayed remediation of 
critical security issues, increasing the risk of exploitation and potential damage to the organization.

controls.title: High coverage of security related module and integration tests

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implementation of security related tests via unit tests and integration tests. Including the test of libraries, in case the are not tested already.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities are rising due to code changes in a complex microservice environment in not important components.

controls.title: Security integration tests for important components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implementation of essential security related integration tests. For example for authentication and authorization.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities are rising due to code changes in a complex microservice environment.

controls.title: Security unit tests for important components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of unit tests to test important security related features like authentication and authorization.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities are rising due to code changes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Integration tests are performed against the production environment after each deployment.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

During a deployment an error might happen which leads to non-availability of the system, a part of the system or a feature.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Findings are visualized per component/project/team.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Correlation of the vulnerabilities of different tools to have an overview of the the overall security level per component/project/team is not given.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implement a simple risk-based prioritization framework for vulnerability remediation based on accessibility of the applications.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Overwhelming volume of security findings from automated testing tools. This might lead to ignorance of findings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Integration of findings into the development process. E.g. adding findings to the backlog of products teams.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not integrating vulnerability handling into the development process may result in product teams ignoring findings. 

Security joke: We will gain 100% false negatives.

controls.title: Integration of vulnerability issues into the development process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerabilities are tracked in the teams issue system (e.g. jira).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

To read console output of the build server to search for vulnerabilities might be difficult. Also, to check a vulnerability management system might not be a daily task for a developer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerabilities include the test procedure to give the staff from operations and development the ability to reproduce vulnerabilities. This enhances the understanding of vulnerabilities and therefore the fix have a higher quality.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerability descriptions are hard to understand by staff from operations and development.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Findings from security tests must be triaged and outcomes persisted/documented to:
  - Prevent re-analysis of known issues in subsequent test runs
  - Track accepted risks vs false positives
  - Enable consistent decision-making across teams

At this maturity level, a simple tracking system suffices - tools need only distinguish between "triaged" and "untriaged" findings, without complex categorization. Some tools refer to this as "suppression" of findings.

Samples for false positive handling:
  - [OWASP Dependency Check](https://jeremylong.github.io/DependencyCheck/general/suppression.html)
  - [Kubescape with VEX](https://kubescape.io/blog/2023/12/07/kubescape-support-for-vex-generation/)
  - [OWASP DefectDojo Risk Acceptance](https://docs.defectdojo.com/en/working_with_findings/findings_workflows/risk_acceptances/) and [False Positive Handling](https://docs.defectdojo.com/en/working_with_findings/intro_to_findings/#triage-vulnerabilities-using-finding-status)

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

As false positive occur during each test, all vulnerabilities might be ignored. Specially, if tests are automated an run daily.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerabilities are simple visualized.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The security level of a component is not visible. Therefore, the motivation to enhance the security is not give.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All vulnerabilities are added to the quality gate.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities with severity low are not visible.

controls.title: Treatment of defects per protection requirement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Defining the protection requirement and the corresponding handling of vulnerabilities per severity for components like applications are aligned to SLAs. 
 This is performed for the hole organization and doesn't need to be broken down (yet) on team/product/application. 
 At least quarterly.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not defining the protection requirement of applications can lead to wrong prioritization, delayed remediation of 
critical security issues, increasing the risk of exploitation and potential damage to the organization.

controls.title: Treatment of defects with severity high or higher

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerabilities with severity high or higher are added to the quality gate.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities with severity high or higher are not visible.

controls.title: Treatment of defects with severity middle

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerabilities with severity middle are added to the quality gate.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities with severity middle are not visible.

controls.title: Usage of a vulnerability management system

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Aggregation of vulnerabilities in one tool reduce the workload to handle them, e.g. mark as false positives.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Maintenance of false positives in each tool enforces a high workload. In addition a correlation of the same finding from different tools is not possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Check that there are no missing paths in the application with coverage-tools.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Parts of the service are not still covered by tests.

controls.title: Coverage of client side dynamic components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of a spider which executes dynamic content like JavaScript, e.g. via Selenium.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Parts of the service are not covered during the scan, because JavaScript is not getting executed. Therefore, the coverage of client-side dynamic components is limited, leading to potential security risks and undetected vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hidden endpoints are getting detected and included in the vulnerability scan.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Hidden endpoints of the service are not getting tracked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Special parameter and special encodings are defined, so that they get fuzzed by the used vulnerability scanners.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Parts of the service are not covered. For example specially formatted or coded parameters are not getting detected as parameter (e.g. parameters in REST-like URLs, parameters in JSON-Format or base64-coded parameters).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Sequential operations are defined and checked by the vulnerability scanner in the defined order.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Sequential operations like workflows (e.g. login -> put products in the basket

controls.title: Coverage of service to service communication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Service to service communication is dumped and checked.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Service to service communication is not covered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A simple scan is performed to get a security baseline. In case the test is done in under 10 minutes, it should be part of the build and deployment process.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Deficient security tests are performed. Simple vulnerabilities are not detected and missing security configurations (e.g. headers) are not set. Fast feedback is not given.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Integration of authentication with all roles used in the service.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Parts of the service are not covered during the scan, because a login is not performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of multiple spiders and scanner enhance the coverage and the vulnerabilities.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Each vulnerability scanner has different opportunities. By using just one scanner, some vulnerabilities might not be found.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Load test against the production system or a production near system is performed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

As it is unknown how many requests the systems and applications can serve, due to an unexpected load the availability is disturbed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With the help of tools the network configuration of unintentional exposed cluster(s) are tested. To identify clusters, all subdomains might need to be identified with a tool like OWASP Amass to perform port scans based o the result.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Standard network segmentation and firewalling has not been performed, leading to world open cluster management ports.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Components must be whitelisted. Regular scans on the docker infrastructure (e.g. cluster) need to be performed, to verify that only standardized base images are used.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unapproved components are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test for unused resources helps to identify unused resources.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unused resources, specially secrets, might be still valid, but are exposing information. As an attacker, I compromise a system, gather credentials and try to use them.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cluster internal test needs to be performed. Integration of fine granulated network segmentation (also between pods in the same namespace).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Wrong or no network segmentation of pods makes it easier for an attacker to access a database and extract or modify data.

controls.title: Test of the configuration of cloud environments

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With the help of tools the configuration of virtual environments are tested.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Standard hardening practices for cloud environments are not performed leading to vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Automatic brute force attacks are performed. Specially the usage of standard accounts like 'admin' and employee user-ids is recommended.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Weak passwords in components like applications or systems, specially for privileged accounts, lead to take over of that account.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Design contract-first APIs using an interface description language such as OpenAPI, AsyncAPI or SOAP
and validate the specification using specific tools.
Checks should be integrated in IDEs and CI/CD pipelines.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Creation of insecure or non-compliant API.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Collection of unused code and then manual removal of unused code.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Dead code increases the attack surface (use of hard coded credentials and variables, sensitive information)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Automatic Detection and manual removal of duplicates in source code.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Duplicates in source code might influence the stability of the application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Estimate the likelihood of exploitation by using data (CISA KEV) from the past or prediction models (EPSS).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Without proper prioritization, organizations may waste time and effort on low-risk vulnerabilities while neglecting critical ones.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Integration of quality and linting plugins with interactive development environment (IDEs).
Implement pre-commit checks to prevent secrets & other security issues being commit to source code.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Creating and developing code contains code smells and quality issues.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Tests for known vulnerabilities in components via Software Composition Analysis of the frontend are performed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Client side components might have vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Tests for known vulnerabilities in server side components (e.g. backend/middleware) are performed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Server side components might have vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of a static analysis for all used components.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Used components like libraries and legacy applications might have vulnerabilities

controls.title: Static analysis for all self written components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of static analysis tools for all parts of the middleware and frontend. Static analysis uses for example string matching algorithms and/or dataflow analysis.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Parts in the source code of the frontend or middleware have vulnerabilities.

controls.title: Static analysis for important client side components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of static analysis tools for important parts of the frontend are used. Static analysis uses for example string matching algorithms and/or dataflow analysis.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Important parts in the source code of the frontend have vulnerabilities.

controls.title: Static analysis for important server side components

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of static analysis tools for important parts of the middleware are used. Static analysis uses for example string matching algorithms and/or dataflow analysis.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Important parts in the source code of the middleware have vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Analysis of compliance to style guides of the source code ensures that source code formatting rules are met (e.g. indentation, loops, ...).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Unclear or obfuscated code might have unexpected behavior.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Test of the Patch Deployment Time.
This activity is not repeated in the Sub-Dimension "Static depth for infrastructure", but it applies to infrastructure as well.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Automatic PRs for dependencies are overlooked resulting in known vulnerabilities in production artifacts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Test of the Time to Patch (e.g. based on Mean Time to Close automatic PRs)
This activity is not repeated in the Sub-Dimension "Static depth for infrastructure", but it applies to infrastructure as well.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Automatic PRs for dependencies are overlooked resulting in known vulnerabilities in production artifacts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test `libyear`, which provides a good insight how good patch management is.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Vulnerabilities in running artifacts stay for long and might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Usage of multiple static tools to find more vulnerabilities.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Each vulnerability analyzer has different opportunities. By using just one analyzer, some vulnerabilities might not be found.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Check logs for keywords.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Not aware of attacks happening.

controls.title: Correlate known vulnerabilities in infrastructure with new image versions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: TODO

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

TODO.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Check for known vulnerabilities

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Known vulnerabilities in infrastructure components like container images might get exploited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test the deployment configuration for virtualized environments for unsecured configurations.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

The deployment configuration (e.g. kubernetes deployment resources) might contain unsecured configurations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Check the image age of containers in production.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Old container images in production indicate that patch management is not performed and therefore vulnerabilities might exists.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Check for malware in components (e.g. container images, VM baseline images, libraries).

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Third party might include  malware. Ether due to the maintainer (e.g. typo squatting of an image name and using the wrong image) or by an attacker on behalf of the maintainer with stolen credentials.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Check for new images of containers in production.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

When a new version of an image is available, it might fix security vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test for secrets in code, container images and history

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Stored secrets in git history, in container images or directly in code shouldn't exists because they might be exposed to unauthorized parties.

controls.title: Test of infrastructure components for known vulnerabilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test for known vulnerabilities in infrastructure components. Often, the only way to respond to known vulnerabilities in operating system packages is to accept the risk and wait for a patch. As the patch needs to be applied fast when it is available, this activity depends on 'Usage of a maximum life for images'.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Infrastructure components might have vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test virtualized environments for unsecured configurations.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Risk: Virtualized environments (e.g. via Container Images) might contains unsecure configurations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With the help of tools, the configuration of virtual environments are tested.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Standard hardening practices for cloud environments are not performed leading to vulnerabilities.

controls.title: Test the definition of virtualized environments

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test the definition of virtualized environments for unsecured configurations.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose: Risk: The definition of virtualized environments (e.g. via Dockerfile) might contain unsecure configurations.

controls.title: Creation and application of a testing concept

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A testing concept considering the amount of time per scan/intensity is created and applied. A dynamic analysis needs more time than a static analysis. The dynamic scan, depending on the test intensity might be performed on every commit, every night, every week or once in a month.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Scans might use a too small or too high test intensity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unneeded tests are deactivated. For example in case the service is using a Mongo database and no mysql database, the dynamic scan doesn't need to test for sql injections.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

As tools cover a wide range of different vulnerability tests, they might not match the used components. Therefore, they need more time and resources as they need and the feedback loops takes too much time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The intensity of the used tools are not modified to save time.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

Time pressure and ignorance might lead to false predictions for the test intensity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A deep scan with high test intensity and a low confidence threshold is performed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

A too small intensity or a too high confidence might lead to not visible vulnerabilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On each push and/or at given intervals automatic security tests are performed.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Risk:

After pushing source code to the version control system, any delay in receiving feedback on defects makes them harder for the developer to remediate.
